posts.name: Alex Richards
posts.cooked:
Team E.L.I.T.E. is proud to present the CAD model for our 2025 robot, xtrēmachēn 28 !

Note: Our team uses SOLIDWORKS, included is a Pack & Go, as well as a .step file of the main assembly. You can find an Onshape import, here .

New Project (4) 600×800 47.2 KB

New Project (4) 600×800 47.2 KB

New Project (4) 600×800 47.2 KB

This is our 28th season of Encouraging Learning In Technology and Engineering. We attended the Rocket City Regional, and joined the #6 alliance with our partners 3058 and 3140. And, we managed to survive the Week 3 regional weather badness that made many events much more difficult.

Next, we attended the Midwest Regional where we joined the #8 alliance with our partners 10438 and 8122. At the end of the event, our team was awarded with the Creativity Award for our differential wrist.

Lastly, we attended the Buckeye Regional where we again joined the #8 alliance with our partners 6181 and 8713.

Our offseason is already off to a fun start. We attended the Ohio State Championship in May, where we captained the 4th alliance with our partners 2399, 4269, and 9622, and finished in 3rd place.

After the Ohio State Championship, we took a chance to reconfigure our robot to improve our algae handling ability, increase our consistency in coral scoring in both tele/auto, and attempt to shed some weight on the telescope.

We took some inspiration from FRC 359, for a single axis wrist and updated manipulator design. This has worked pretty well for us so far, and we’d like to thank 359 for answering some questions we had about the design. The design of our robot with our offseason updates can be found in the Google Drive link above, as well as the Onshape import here .

image 532×945 93.2 KB

image 532×945 93.2 KB

image 532×945 93.2 KB

We attended Battlecry with this redesign, where we joined the #1 alliance with our friends from our first BC trip 1768, and new friends of 88 and 3182.

Below you can find handouts which our students present and hand out to judges.

XM28_Page1 1440×1864 333 KB

XM28_Page1 1440×1864 333 KB

XM28_Page1 1440×1864 333 KB

XM28_Page2 1440×1864 284 KB

XM28_Page2 1440×1864 284 KB

XM28_Page2 1440×1864 284 KB

You can catch us at some other offseason events this year. We are attending the FAMNM Wolverine Robotics Competition in August, and are evaluating a select few others in the September - October timeframe.

For any questions about our 2025 robot, feel free to reach out to myself or @A_Reed in this thread, or though DM’s. Good luck next season in Rebuilt and thanks for reading!
Can you explain how the top bevel gear is attached to the “shaft block” that all 3 bevel gears ride on?  Looked at the CAD and I just can’t see what magic you used Cheers.

posts.name: Alex Richards
posts.cooked:
Here’s a section view of the differential. There is a metal billet machined hub that is pressed into the top bevel gear (green square). That is inserted into the shaft block through 2 bearings, and retained with a small plate (yellow square) and 6x 4-40 bolts (red).

image 986×542 119 KB

image 986×542 119 KB

image 986×542 119 KB

This proved to be pretty robust. This let us pass wires directly through the center axis and keep the range of motion we wanted.

Alex, trying to figure out how the top gear is attached to the shaft block.  Is the machined hub pressed through the yellow retainer ring and into the shaft block and the 4x40 bolts then hold the retainer ring to the top bevel gear?

Cheers.

posts.name: Alex Richards
posts.cooked:
The machined hub is passed through the two bearings in the hub, which constrain the motion to pure rotation at the gear. The yellow retaining ring gets bolted to the machined hub, preventing the hub/gear from falling out.

The yellow plate is bolted between the bearing to constrain that axial motion. Without it, there is the potential for the top gear (which mount the gripper) to fall out.
